title: 113_s1687
content: The "Payroll Fraud Prevention Act of 2013" is the short title of this Act. It includes a section on the classification of employees and non-employees. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 has been amended to define 'Non-employee' as an individual engaged for labor or services by a person in the course of their business, but not as an employee. 'Covered individual' refers to an employee or non-employee engaged for labor or services by an employer or person required to file an information return. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 has been amended to include individuals providing labor or services to a person through an entity like a trust, estate, partnership, association, company, or corporation. This applies if the individual has an ownership interest in the entity, the entity's creation or maintenance is a condition for providing labor or services, and the person would be required to file an information return for the entity under the Internal Revenue Code. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 has been amended to include individuals providing labor or services to a person through an entity like a trust, estate, partnership, association, company, or corporation. Section 6041A(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is referenced for individuals with an ownership interest in the entity. Amendments to Section 11(c) of the Fair Labor Standards Act include recordkeeping and classification requirements for employers and enterprises engaging employees in commerce or the production of goods. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 has been amended to include classification requirements for employers engaging individuals in commerce or the production of goods. Employers must accurately classify each individual as an employee or non-employee and provide written notice to inform them of their classification. This notice should direct individuals to the Department of Labor website for more information. The Department of Labor website, established under the Payroll Fraud Prevention Act of 2013, provides information on legal rights of employees, including contact details for local offices. Non-employees must be informed of their rights with a specific statement. The Department of Labor website provides information on employee rights and contact details for local offices. Non-employees must receive a specific statement regarding their classification and rights. The Payroll Fraud Prevention Act of 2013 requires notices to be provided to covered individuals within 6 months of enactment, and subsequently to new employees and non-employees upon employment or commencement of services. Additionally, individuals must be notified of any change in their status. The Payroll Fraud Prevention Act of 2013 mandates notices to covered individuals within 6 months of enactment, and to new employees or non-employees upon employment. A covered individual is presumed an employee if not provided notice within the required time, rebuttable only with clear evidence. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to prohibit discrimination against covered individuals for opposing certain practices or filing complaints related to the Act. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to prohibit discrimination against covered individuals for opposing certain practices or filing complaints related to the Act, including wrongly classifying an employee as a non-employee. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to impose special penalties for misclassification, recordkeeping, and notice violations for covered individuals. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to impose special penalties for misclassification, recordkeeping, and notice violations for covered individuals. Such liquidated damages are doubled for violations of section 6 or 7, subject to the Portal-to-Portal Act of 1947. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to impose special penalties for violations of section 6, 7, 11(c), or 15(a)(6). Violators may be subject to civil penalties up to $1,100 per violation, or up to $5,000 for repeat or willful violations. The Secretary of Labor will create a webpage summarizing employee rights under the Fair Labor Standards Act within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, there will be penalties for misclassifying employees for unemployment compensation purposes. The Social Security Act is amended to include auditing procedures to identify non-compliant employers and unreported wages, with quarterly reports to the Secretary of Labor required. The Secretary of Labor will establish administrative penalties for misclassifying employees or paying unreported wages without proper recordkeeping for unemployment compensation purposes. The Department of Labor will measure States' performance in identifying underreported wages and underpayment of unemployment compensation contributions. The amendments made by subsection (a) of the Act will take effect 12 months after enactment, unless a State requires legislation to comply, in which case the amendments will apply later of the close of the first regular session of the State legislature or 12 months after enactment. The term "State" is defined as per section 3306(j) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 5. Department of Labor coordination, referral, and regulations. (a) Coordination and Referral.--Any office, administration, or division of the Department of Labor obtaining information on misclassification under the Fair Labor Standards Act must report it to the Wage and Hour Division, which may further report to the Internal Revenue Service. (b) The Secretary of Labor will issue regulations. The Secretary of Labor will issue regulations to implement the Act and its amendments. Targeted audits of employers under the Fair Labor Standards Act will focus on industries prone to misclassifying employees as non-employees, as determined by the Secretary of Labor.
